... and friends. Also rename `prod_of_empty` to `prod_of_isEmpty`.

### PR summary [9b5aa783d5](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13726/commits/9b5aa783d51105d1d58c006834f252c5ef9815b5)

#### Declarations diff

`+ sum_of_isEmpty`
`++- sum_of_empty`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
```

🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by faenuccio.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9538445389/job/26287654802)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9538445389/job/26287654926)
From the user point of view, it seems to me that the ordering `f,g,h` is more natural than `h,f,g`.
Given that `h` is an hypothesis, it should come first. Indeed, all uses in mathlib fill in `h` but don't specify `f` and `g`.
~~Same comment as for the false version about the order of variables.~~ Forget

```suggestion
        ← sum_subset subset_union_right, sum_ite_of_true,
        sum_ite_of_true, ← mul_sum, ← mul_sum, hw₁, hw₁', ← add_mul, hab,
        mul_one] <;> intros <;> simp_all
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: Golf `Finset.prod_ite_of_true`
